SEARCH
Package sh.brane.rpc

Class WebSocketProvider

java.lang.Object
sh.brane.rpc.WebSocketProvider
All Implemented Interfaces:
AutoCloseable, BraneProvider
public class WebSocketProvider extends Object implements BraneProvider, AutoCloseable
Ultra-low latency WebSocket provider using Netty and LMAX Disruptor.

Thread Safety: This class is thread-safe. Multiple threads can safely call send(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>), sendAsync(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>), and sendAsyncBatch(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>) concurrently. Request tracking uses an AtomicReferenceArray with CAS-based slot allocation to prevent race conditions between the caller threads, Disruptor thread, and Netty I/O thread.

Optimizations:

  • Zero-allocation JSON serialization directly to ByteBuf
  • Low-allocation response parsing from ByteBuf
  • Lock-free request ID generation using AtomicLong
  • CAS-based slot allocation for thread-safe request tracking
  • Batched writes with flush on end-of-batch
  • Optimized Netty channel options (TCP_NODELAY, etc.)
  • Large ring buffer for high throughput bursts

  • Method Details

    • setSubscriptionExecutor

      public void setSubscriptionExecutor(Executor executor)
      Sets a custom executor for subscription callbacks.

      By default, subscription callbacks run on virtual threads to avoid blocking the Netty I/O thread. Use this method to provide a custom executor if you need specific threading behavior (e.g., a bounded pool, or the same thread as Netty).

      Warning: If you set an executor that runs callbacks on the Netty I/O thread (or any single thread), ensure callbacks complete quickly. Blocking operations will stall all WebSocket I/O.

      Lifecycle: User-provided executors are NOT closed when close() is called. The caller is responsible for managing the lifecycle of custom executors.

      Parameters:
      executor - the executor to use for subscription callbacks (must not be null)
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if executor is null

    • setMetrics

      public void setMetrics(BraneMetrics metrics)
      Sets a custom metrics collector for observability.

      Use this to integrate with monitoring systems like Micrometer, Prometheus, or custom metrics collectors.

      Parameters:
      metrics - the metrics collector (must not be null)
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if metrics is null

    • getOrphanedResponseCount

      public long getOrphanedResponseCount()
      Returns the total count of orphaned responses received since this provider was created.

      Orphaned responses are responses received with no matching pending request. This typically occurs when:

      • The response ID cannot be parsed
      • The request timed out before the response arrived
      • The request was cancelled

      This metric is useful for monitoring connection health. High orphan counts may indicate network issues, server-side delays, or timeout values that are too aggressive.

      Returns:
      the total count of orphaned responses
      Since:
      0.5.0

    • getConnectionState

      public WebSocketProvider.ConnectionState getConnectionState()
      Returns the current connection state.

      This method is useful for monitoring and diagnostics. Clients can use this to check whether the provider is connected, reconnecting, or closed before attempting operations.

      Thread safety: This method returns a snapshot of the current state. The state may change immediately after this method returns.

      Returns:
      the current WebSocketProvider.ConnectionState
      Since:
      0.5.0

    • getPendingRequestCount

      public int getPendingRequestCount()
      Returns the current number of pending requests awaiting responses.

      This metric is useful for monitoring backpressure and connection health. A consistently high pending request count may indicate:

      • Network latency issues
      • Server-side processing delays
      • Request rate exceeding response throughput

      Thread safety: This method returns a snapshot of the current count. The count may change immediately after this method returns due to concurrent request submission or response processing.

      Returns:
      the number of pending requests
      Since:
      0.6.0

    • create

      public static WebSocketProvider create(WebSocketConfig config)
      Creates a new WebSocketProvider with the specified configuration.

      Use this method for full control over provider settings including:

      • Max pending requests (backpressure limit)
      • Disruptor ring buffer size
      • Wait strategy (YIELDING for low latency, BLOCKING for CPU efficiency)
      • Default request timeout
      • Number of I/O threads
      Parameters:
      config - the WebSocket configuration
      Returns:
      a connected WebSocketProvider instance
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - if connection fails
      See Also:
      • WebSocketConfig.builder(String)

    • create

      public static WebSocketProvider create(String url)
      Creates a new WebSocketProvider and connects to the specified URL.

      The provider supports both ws:// and wss:// schemes. SSL/TLS is automatically configured for secure connections.

      Parameters:
      url - the WebSocket URL to connect to (e.g., "wss://ethereum.publicnode.com")
      Returns:
      a connected WebSocketProvider instance
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - if connection fails

    • send

      public JsonRpcResponse send(String method, List<?> params) throws RpcException
      Sends a synchronous JSON-RPC request and blocks until the response is received.

      This method wraps sendAsync(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>) and waits for completion. For better performance in high-throughput scenarios, prefer sendAsync(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>) or sendAsyncBatch(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>).

      Specified by:
      send in interface BraneProvider
      Parameters:
      method - the JSON-RPC method name (e.g., "eth_blockNumber")
      params - the method parameters, or null/empty for no parameters
      Returns:
      the JSON-RPC response
      Throws:
      RpcException - if the request fails or returns an error

    • sendAsync

      public CompletableFuture<JsonRpcResponse> sendAsync(String method, List<?> params)
      Sends an asynchronous JSON-RPC request.

      The request is serialized directly to a ByteBuf with zero intermediate String allocations. The returned future completes when the response is received.

      For batch scenarios with many concurrent requests, consider using sendAsyncBatch(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>) which uses the Disruptor for optimal batching.

      Parameters:
      method - the JSON-RPC method name (e.g., "eth_chainId")
      params - the method parameters, or null/empty for no parameters
      Returns:
      a CompletableFuture that completes with the JSON-RPC response

    • sendAsync

      public CompletableFuture<JsonRpcResponse> sendAsync(String method, List<?> params, Duration timeout)
      Sends an asynchronous JSON-RPC request with a custom timeout.

      The request is serialized directly to a ByteBuf with zero intermediate String allocations. The returned future completes when the response is received or when the timeout expires.

      Parameters:
      method - the JSON-RPC method name (e.g., "eth_chainId")
      params - the method parameters, or null/empty for no parameters
      timeout - the timeout duration for this request; if null, no timeout is applied
      Returns:
      a CompletableFuture that completes with the JSON-RPC response or exceptionally on timeout

    • sendAsyncBatch

      public CompletableFuture<JsonRpcResponse> sendAsyncBatch(String method, List<?> params)
      Sends an asynchronous JSON-RPC request using the Disruptor ring buffer.

      This method is optimized for high-throughput scenarios where many requests are sent in rapid succession. Requests are batched and flushed together, reducing syscall overhead. Uses the configured default request timeout.

      Use this method when:

      • Sending many requests in a tight loop
      • Maximum throughput is more important than individual request latency
      • You want automatic batching of network writes
      Parameters:
      method - the JSON-RPC method name
      params - the method parameters, or null/empty for no parameters
      Returns:
      a CompletableFuture that completes with the JSON-RPC response
      See Also:
      • for custom timeout support

    • sendAsyncBatch

      public CompletableFuture<JsonRpcResponse> sendAsyncBatch(String method, List<?> params, Duration timeout)
      Sends an asynchronous JSON-RPC request optimized for high-throughput batching, with a custom timeout.

      Same as sendAsyncBatch(String, List) but allows specifying a custom timeout for this request. The timeout applies to the individual request, not the batch write.

      Parameters:
      method - the JSON-RPC method name
      params - the method parameters, or null/empty for no parameters
      timeout - the timeout duration for this request; if null, no timeout is applied
      Returns:
      a CompletableFuture that completes with the JSON-RPC response or exceptionally on timeout

    • subscribe

      public String subscribe(String method, List<?> params, Consumer<Object> callback) throws RpcException
      Subscribes to a real-time event stream using eth_subscribe.

      Supported subscription types include:

      • newHeads - new block headers
      • logs - contract event logs (with optional filter)
      • newPendingTransactions - pending transaction hashes

      The callback is invoked on the Netty I/O thread. Avoid blocking operations in the callback to prevent I/O thread starvation.

      Specified by:
      subscribe in interface BraneProvider
      Parameters:
      method - the subscription type (e.g., "newHeads", "logs")
      params - additional parameters (e.g., log filter for "logs" subscription)
      callback - invoked for each notification with the event data
      Returns:
      the subscription ID, which can be used to unsubscribe(java.lang.String)
      Throws:
      RpcException - if subscription fails

    • unsubscribe

      public boolean unsubscribe(String subscriptionId) throws RpcException
      Unsubscribes from a previously created subscription.
      Specified by:
      unsubscribe in interface BraneProvider
      Parameters:
      subscriptionId - the subscription ID returned by subscribe(java.lang.String, java.util.List<?>, java.util.function.Consumer<java.lang.Object>)
      Returns:
      true if the subscription was successfully cancelled
      Throws:
      RpcException - if the unsubscribe request fails

    • close

      public void close()
      Closes the WebSocket connection and releases all resources.

      This method:

      • Fails any pending requests with an exception
      • Shuts down the Disruptor
      • Closes the WebSocket channel
      • Shuts down the subscription executor (only if created internally)
      • Shuts down the Netty event loop group (only if created internally)

      Resource ownership: Externally-provided resources are NOT closed:

      • If an EventLoopGroup was provided via WebSocketConfig.eventLoopGroup(), it will NOT be shut down.
      • If a custom executor was set via setSubscriptionExecutor(Executor), it will NOT be shut down.

      The caller is responsible for managing the lifecycle of externally-provided resources.

      After calling close(), this provider cannot be reused.

      Specified by:
      close in interface AutoCloseable
      Specified by:
      close in interface BraneProvider
